raw_text:
Davenport puts retirement on hold
 
 Lindsay Davenport has put any talk of retirement on hold after having a largely injury-free 2004 campaign.
 
 The 28-year-old world number one had said that she would quit at the end of last year, but after a successful season she has had a change of heart. "Finally I felt I put myself in a position to try and win Grand Slams again," said Davenport. "It would be tough to walk away when I feel like I can contend so there's no point in hanging it up quite yet." Davenport has won three Grand Slams, the 2000 Australian Open, Wimbledon in 1999 and the 1998 US Open. Her career has been hit by a series of injuries but last year she started hitting top form and won seven titles. She was due to take part in this week's Hopman Cup in Perth but decided she wanted to rest her knee. "I just really wanted to make sure my right knee was going to be able to really withstand all the rigours of the whole year coming up," she said.
llama3.2:1b: Lindsay Davenport has put retirement on hold due to a change of heart after winning three Grand Slams in 2004 and having success with seven titles last year, prompting her to re-evaluate her career plans.
llama3.2:3b: Lindsay Davenport has put retirement on hold after a largely injury-free 2004 season, feeling confident that she can contend for Grand Slams again. She had previously planned to retire at the end of last year but now feels it's not the right time.
gemma2:2b: Lindsay Davenport has decided to postpone retirement after a successful 2004 season.  She had planned to retire at the end of last year, but her recent success has motivated her to continue competing for Grand Slam titles. Davenport won three Grand Slams and is taking precautions to protect her knee as she prepares for the upcoming year.

She had previously stated that her final plans were to quit at the end of last year's season, but since then she has changed her mind and decided to continue playing until August.

Initially considering retirement at the end of 2003, she now feels capable of competing for more titles and will continue her career despite resting her knee ahead of the Hopman Cup in Perth.

After winning three Grand Slams, Davenport is now hit by injuries but continues to win in these competitions and achieve the top record for winning in the Australian Open at only 19th in 1999 and the US Open at only 1998.

"Finally I felt I put myself in a position to try and win Grand Slams again," said Davenport. "It would be tough to walk away when I feel like I can contend so there's no point in hanging it up quite yet." Davenport has won three Grand Slams, the 2000 Australian Open, Wimbledon in 1999 and the 1998 US Open. Her career has been hit by a series of injuries but last year she started hitting top form and won seven titles. She was due to take part in this week's Hopman Cup in Perth but decided she wanted to rest her knee. "I just really wanted to make sure my right knee was going to be able to really withstand all the rigours of the whole year coming up," she said.

Lindsay Davenport has decided not to retake retirement following her largely injury-free 2004 campaign. She won three Grand Slams—the 2000 Australian Open, Wimbledon in '99, and the 1998 US Open—and had a successful season before changing her mind. Last year, she hit top form and secured seven titles. This week, she'll compete in the Hopman Cup in Perth but is choosing to rest her knee.

She was expected to participate in this week's Hopman Cup but decided instead to rest and prepare for a full calendar year ahead.

The world number one had initially announced her intention to retire following last year's injury-free campaign, but with a change of heart she is now considering pursuing a comeback. Davenport has won three Grand Slam titles and achieved a remarkable career-high ranking of number one in 1998.

stablelm-zephyr:3b: Lindsay Davenport, a 28-year-old world number one tennis player, has postponed her retirement after having an injury-free 2004 season. She had previously announced her intention to quit at the end of 2003 but changed her mind after winning seven titles in 2004 and feeling she could contend for Grand Slams. Davenport has won three Grand Slams: the 2000 Australian Open, Wimbledon in 1999, and the 1998 US Open. Despite facing a series of injuries throughout her career, she decided to rest her knee ahead of this week's Hopman Cup in Perth to ensure it could withstand the rigours of the upcoming year.

The world number one had planned to quit but changed her mind after regaining top form and winning seven titles. She believes she can still compete for Grand Slams, having previously won three majors. Though she was set to play in the Hopman Cup, she opted to rest her knee to ensure it can endure the upcoming season.
stablelm2:1.6b: Lindsay Davenport temporarily suspends retirement after a successful injury-free tennis season. With three Grand Slams under her belt (Australian Open, Wimbledon, US Open), Davenport remains hopeful for future success despite dealing with ongoing knee issues.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Lindsay Davenport, the 28-year-old world number one tennis player, has postponed her retirement plans following an injury-free and successful 2004 season. She had previously announced her intention to retire at year's end due to persistent injuries, which have hindered her career. However, Davenport's performance improved significantly last year, earning seven titles and feeling capable of contending for Grand Slams once more. Despite participating in this week's Hopman Cup in Perth, she opted to rest her right knee, emphasizing the importance of its health for the upcoming demanding year ahead. Davenport has previously won three Grand Slams: the 2000 Australian Open, Wimbledon in 1999, and the 1998 US Open.
